You said:
"$2b$10$sNG7Kk71JJrYQrNxbGWfNOw0pH.zALEnz3yiy17PzWOYo5hzgbMO6" for this hashed password how do i get the actual password that i used to create in mysql
ChatGPT said:

You cannot retrieve the original password from a bcrypt hash like:

perl
$2b$10$sNG7Kk71JJrYQrNxbGWfNOw0pH.zALEnz3yiy17PzWOYo5hzgbMO6

This is by design — bcrypt is a one-way hashing algorithm, meaning it is not reversible. You can't "decrypt" it to get the original password.

What You Can Do Instead

To check if a user entered the correct password:

  1. User enters password: e.g., mypassword123

  2. You hash the entered password using bcrypt and compare it with the stored hash.

In Node.js, for example:

js
const bcrypt = require('bcrypt');

const storedHash = "$2b$10$sNG7Kk71JJrYQrNxbGWfNOw0pH.zALEnz3yiy17PzWOYo5hzgbMO6";
const enteredPassword = "your_guess_here"; // this is the password the user types

bcrypt.compare(enteredPassword, storedHash, (err, result) => {
  if (result) {
    console.log("Password matches!");
  } else {
    console.log("Incorrect password.");
  }
});

Tip: When Developing Locally

If you’ve forgotten what password you used to generate that hash during testing, you can:

  • Try different likely passwords using bcrypt.compare() in a script.

  • Generate a new hash using a known password, like:

js
const password = "newPassword123";
const saltRounds = 10;

bcrypt.hash(password, saltRounds, (err, hash) => {
  console.log("New hash:", hash);
});

Then, update the database with this new hash.

Would you like help writing a quick script to test password guesses against that hash?

You said:
upon logging in page not found is getting displayed only after clicking on an AppBar icon and clicking on refresh page button its displaying the dashboard links. and also logging in as a staff Member its still opening up clients
ChatGPT said:
Reasoned about login and routing issues for 4 seconds

It sounds like you’re encountering two related issues:

  1. After login you’re seeing “Page Not Found” until you manually refresh via an AppBar icon.

  2. When logging in as a staff member, the application is routing to the “Clients” view rather than the expected dashboard for that role.

Below are some detailed troubleshooting steps and recommendations that might help you pinpoint and fix these issues:

1. “Page Not Found” After Login

Routing Initialization / Asynchronous Loading

  • Delayed Routing Data:
    It’s possible that your router or navigation state isn’t fully set up by the time the login process completes. For instance, if your application loads user-specific routes (or menu items) asynchronously (after fetching user data), the router might try to navigate to a route that isn’t yet registered.
    Recommendation:

    • Ensure that the user’s role and corresponding routes are fully loaded and available before redirecting. For example, you might want to delay the redirection until after the user’s dashboard or permitted routes are confirmed.

Browser History or Base URL Issues

  • Server vs. Client Route Resolution:
    If you’re using a modern framework (React Router, Angular Router, Vue Router) with HTML5 history mode, a manual refresh might resolve the route because the server is configured to serve the index file for unknown paths. However, if that setup isn’t correctly handling the login redirection, you might see a “Page Not Found” until you reload.
    Recommendation:

    • Double-check your server configuration (for instance, using a catch-all route) to ensure that any client-side routing is properly handled.

    • If using a static file server, consider switching to hash mode (if acceptable) or ensuring that the fallback is set correctly.

UI State vs. Application State

  • AppBar Behavior:
    The fact that clicking an AppBar icon and then a refresh makes your dashboard links appear may indicate that the AppBar component triggers a state update or re-fetch of the route definitions.
    Recommendation:

    • Inspect the lifecycle of your navigation components. If the AppBar click triggers a state refresh or call (such as reloading user roles or permissions), consider running that logic as soon as the login completes.

    • Verify that your client-side state management (e.g., Redux, Vuex, Context API) is propagating the authenticated state and route configuration correctly from the login event onward.

2. Staff Member Routing to “Clients”

Role-Based Redirect Logic

  • Misconfigured Role Checks:
    When a staff member logs in, your application might be using a default redirection logic that’s not differentiating between user types properly. For example, if the default landing route is set to “Clients” irrespective of role, then staff might see the wrong page.
    Recommendation:

    • Review the routing logic or guard conditions that check the user role. Make sure the conditions are distinct between staff and other types (e.g., admin or client) so that each role is directed to its appropriate landing page.

    • If you’re using route guards (or middleware), verify that your logic explicitly specifies the correct route for staff members.

Example (Pseudo-code)

If you’re using a framework like React Router, your routing might look something like this:

js
function getDefaultRouteForUser(role) {
  switch(role) {
    case 'admin':
      return '/admin/dashboard';
    case 'staff':
      return '/staff/dashboard'; // adjust this to your desired route
    case 'client':
      return '/clients'; // this might be the default for clients
    default:
      return '/login';
  }
}

// After a successful login:
const redirectTo = getDefaultRouteForUser(loggedInUser.role);
history.push(redirectTo);

Make sure that the routes (/staff/dashboard in this example) exist and are correctly configured in your route definitions.

General Debugging Steps

  1. Check the Console and Network Tab:
    Look for any errors or failed network requests when login occurs. Sometimes a missing resource or a JavaScript error can halt the execution of your routing logic.

  2. Examine State Management:
    If your application relies on client-side state management to store the authentication token and user role, ensure that the state is updated immediately after login. If there’s any delay, it might cause a fallback to a default (or incorrect) route.

  3. Review Lifecycle Hooks:
    If using frameworks like Angular or Vue, verify that your route guards or lifecycle hooks (e.g., ngOnInit or created) are correctly detecting the authenticated state and user role before routing.

  4. Test Different Scenarios:

    • Try logging in with different user roles (staff vs. client vs. admin) to see if the redirection logic is consistently applying the right rule.

    • Use debugging tools to trace the flow of your login and redirection process.

  5. Simplify for Debugging:
    Temporarily hard-code the redirection after login to see if bypassing dynamic role checks resolves the “Page Not Found” issue. This can help isolate if the problem is with the dynamic configuration logic or with the router setup in general.

Conclusion

The issues you described suggest that there may be a race condition or misconfiguration in your routing logic and role-based redirection. By ensuring that the application’s route definitions are fully loaded and that the login process properly updates the user role state before redirection, you can likely resolve the “Page Not Found” error. Similarly, auditing the role-check logic should address the issue of staff members being directed to the “Clients” view.

If you can provide additional details about the framework or share snippets of your routing configuration and login code, more tailored advice can be given. Otherwise, the above troubleshooting steps should give you a solid starting point.

ChatGPT said:

Thank you for sharing your code. You're close — let’s break this down to solve both the "Page Not Found" issue and the role-based routing mismatch.

✅ What’s Working

  • You're correctly storing user, role, and token in localStorage.

  • You're using navigate() to redirect after login based on userData.role.

  • You’ve implemented a React context (AuthContext) that restores login state from localStorage.

🔍 Problem 1: Page Not Found Until Refresh

This is very likely caused by React Router not having access to the user's role-based redirect logic on initial load, because:

  • Your AuthProvider's useEffect() sets the state after reading from localStorage, which takes place after the route decision has already happened.

  • This causes a brief moment where the app thinks the user is not authenticated, and shows a fallback route (likely your 404 or “Page Not Found” route).

  • Then, once the context loads the stored auth state, things “fix themselves” after you click or refresh.

✅ Fix: Add a loading state to AuthContext

Update AuthContext to include a loading flag that is true while checking localStorage:

js
export const AuthProvider = ({ children }) => {
  const [authState, setAuthState] = useState({
    isAuthenticated: false,
    user: null,
    role: null,
  });
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); // NEW

  useEffect(() => {
    const storedUser = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("user"));
    const storedRole = localStorage.getItem("role");

    if (storedUser && storedRole) {
      setAuthState({
        isAuthenticated: true,
        user: storedUser,
        role: storedRole,
      });
    }

    setLoading(false); // SET TO FALSE after checking
  }, []);

  const login = (data) => {
    localStorage.setItem("user", JSON.stringify(data.user));
    localStorage.setItem("role", data.role);
    localStorage.setItem("token", data.token);

    setAuthState({
      isAuthenticated: true,
      user: data.user,
      role: data.role,
    });
  };

  const logout = () => {
    localStorage.clear();
    setAuthState({
      isAuthenticated: false,
      user: null,
      role: null,
    });
  };

  return (
    <AuthContext.Provider value={{ authState, login, logout, loading }}>
      {children}
    </AuthContext.Provider>
  );
};

Then in your route protection or root app component (where routing happens), you check if loading === true and show a loading spinner or nothing.

Example in App.js or AppRoutes.js:

jsx
const { loading } = useContext(AuthContext);

if (loading) return <div>Loading...</div>; // Or a spinner

return (
  <Routes>
    {/* your protected and public routes */}
  </Routes>
);

🔍 Problem 2: Logging in as Staff still opens Client view

This is usually one of these:

🔁 Mismatch Between navigate() Path and Route Definitions

You wrote:

js
navigate("/manager");

But your actual route might be something like:

jsx
<Route path="/manager-dashboard" element={<ManagerDashboard />} />

If that’s the case, React Router will not find /manager and you'll get “Page Not Found.”

✅ Fix: Match the path to your route definitions

If your route is:

jsx
<Route path="/manager-dashboard" element={<ManagerDashboard />} />

Then your login redirect should be:

js
navigate("/manager-dashboard");

So update this part of your login function in LoginDialog.js:

js
if (userData.role === "Manager") {
  navigate("/manager-dashboard"); // match route
} else if (userData.role === "Staff") {
  navigate("/staff-dashboard"); // match route
} else if (userData.role === "Client") {
  navigate("/client-dashboard"); // match route
}

Make sure those routes actually exist and are registered in your AppRoutes.js or wherever you're handling <Routes>.

✅ Bonus: Avoid Hardcoding in Multiple Places

Create a simple map of roles to dashboard paths to avoid repetitive if/else logic:

js
const roleRedirects = {
  Manager: "/manager-dashboard",
  Staff: "/staff-dashboard",
  Client: "/client-dashboard",
};

navigate(roleRedirects[userData.role] || "/");

✅ Summary

  • ✅ Add loading state in AuthContext to prevent “Page Not Found” on first render.

  • ✅ Match the navigate() paths in your login logic to your actual route paths.

  • ✅ (Optional) Use a role-to-path map for cleaner role-based redirection.

Would you like help checking your AppRoutes.js or ProtectedRoute setup next to ensure it's wired correctly for this role-based access?

Thanks for sharing the full AppRoutes.js and ProtectedRoute.js — your structure looks good overall. You're very close, but based on what you shared, here's a clear diagnosis of the issues and how to fix them:

🔎 1. “Page Not Found” or Wrong Dashboard on Login

Root Cause

You're navigating to /manager, /staff, or /client after login, but your actual dashboard routes are:

  • ✅ /managers-dashboard

  • ✅ /staff-dashboard

  • ✅ /clients-dashboard

So when you navigate to /manager, it doesn’t exist, resulting in a 404 ("Page Not Found").

✅ Fix this in your LoginDialog.js:

Replace this logic:

js
if (userData.role === "Manager") {
  navigate("/manager");
} else if (userData.role === "Staff") {
  navigate("/staff");
} else if (userData.role === "Client") {
  navigate("/client");
}

With the correct route paths:

js
if (userData.role === "Manager") {
  navigate("/managers-dashboard");
} else if (userData.role === "Staff") {
  navigate("/staff-dashboard");
} else if (userData.role === "Client") {
  navigate("/clients-dashboard");
}

Or, even better, use a mapping:

js
const roleToRoute = {
  Manager: "/managers-dashboard",
  Staff: "/staff-dashboard",
  Client: "/clients-dashboard",
};

navigate(roleToRoute[userData.role]);

🔎 2. Double useContext in AppRoutes

In your AppRoutes:

js
const { authState } = useContext(AuthContext);
const { loading } = useContext(AuthContext);

✅ Fix: Use only one useContext() call

js
const { authState, loading } = useContext(AuthContext);

🔎 3. Redirect Logic in ProtectedRoute

This is good:

js
if (!authState.isAuthenticated) {
  return <Navigate to="/" replace />;
}

But this can misbehave if:

  • Auth state hasn't finished loading yet.

  • authState.role is undefined or delayed.

✅ Recommendation:

Add a check for authState.role just in case:

js
if (!authState.isAuthenticated || !authState.role) {
  return <Navigate to="/login" replace />;
}

🔎 4. Landing Route Redirect Logic ("/")

This logic is correct:

jsx
<Route
  path="/"
  element={

      authState.role === "Manager" ? (

      ) : authState.role === "Staff" ? (
        <Navigate to="/staff-dashboard" />
      ) : (
        <Navigate to="/clients-dashboard" />
      )

      <Navigate to="/login" />
    )
  }
/>

✅ Make sure you're calling navigate("/") after login if you're relying on this to route based on role.

But you already have more explicit redirects, so it's fine either way.

If Staff login is still opening the Client Dashboard (/clients-dashboard) even after fixing route paths, then the problem is likely in the role returned by the backend or stored in authState.

Let’s walk through the debug checklist and fixes to find the root cause:

✅ 1. Check What Role Is Returned on Login

In your login response handler (likely in LoginLandingPage.js or LoginDialog.js), log the returned user data:

js
console.log("Login response data:", userData);

Specifically, make sure userData.role === "Staff" when logging in as staff.

✅ 2. Verify Role Is Set Correctly in AuthContext

In AuthContext.js, ensure you're setting authState.role correctly when login succeeds:

js
setAuthState({
  isAuthenticated: true,
  role: userData.role, // MUST be "Manager", "Staff", or "Client"
  user: userData,       // Optional but helpful
});

If userData.role is accidentally set to "Client" or is missing, you will be routed to the wrong dashboard.

🔍 Add this for debugging:

js
console.log("Setting authState with role:", userData.role);

✅ 3. Check AppRoutes.js Landing Route Logic

You already have:

jsx
<Route
  path="/"
  element={
    authState.isAuthenticated ? (
      authState.role === "Manager" ? (
        <Navigate to="/managers-dashboard" />
      ) : authState.role === "Staff" ? (
        <Navigate to="/staff-dashboard" />
      ) : (
        <Navigate to="/clients-dashboard" />
      )
    ) : (
      <Navigate to="/login" />
    )
  }
/>

This is good — but if authState.role is wrong (e.g., still "Client"), it will route incorrectly.

✅ 4. Fix: Add Console Logs in Key Places

Add logs in the login component:

js
console.log("userData.role from login response:", userData.role);

And inside AppRoutes:

js
console.log("authState.role in AppRoutes:", authState.role);

If both log "Client" for a staff login, your backend is misidentifying the user.

✅ 5. Check Backend Login Response

Make sure the backend sends the correct role from the staff table:

js
res.json({
  message: "Login successful",
  user: {
    StaffID: staff.StaffID,
    FullName: staff.FullName,
    Email: staff.Email,
    Role: staff.Role, // <-- Make sure this is "Staff"
  },
});

In the frontend, ensure you're reading it as:

js
const userData = response.user;

If your backend mistakenly assigns "Client" as the role for all users, it will always route them to the client dashboard.

✅ 1. Fix Layout to a Vertical Form

If fields and button are side-by-side, you're likely using display: inline or placing everything inside a <div> without proper styling.

Here's a clean form layout using flexbox column layout:

jsx
import React, { useState, useContext } from "react";
import { AuthContext } from "../context/AuthContext";
import "./LoginLandingPage.css"; // Create this CSS file if not done already

const LoginLandingPage = () => {
  const { login } = useContext(AuthContext);
  const [email, setEmail] = useState("");
  const [password, setPassword] = useState("");
  const [role, setRole] = useState("Client");

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    login(email, password, role); // Ensure your login function supports role
  };

  return (
    <div className="login-container">
      <h2>Login to Elegant Touch Nails</h2>
      <form onSubmit={handleSubmit} className="login-form">
        <label>
          Email:
          <input
            type="email"
            value={email}
            onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)}
            required
          />
        </label>

        <label>
          Password:
          <input
            type="password"
            value={password}
            onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
            required
          />
        </label>

        <label>
          Role:
          <select value={role} onChange={(e) => setRole(e.target.value)} required>

            <option value="Staff">Staff</option>
            <option value="Client">Client</option>

jsx
// src/pages/LoginLandingPage.js

import React, { useState, useContext, useEffect } from "react";
import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom";
import { AuthContext } from "../context/AuthContext";
import "./LoginLandingPage.css";

const LoginLandingPage = () => {
  const { login, authState } = useContext(AuthContext);
  const navigate = useNavigate();

  const [email, setEmail] = useState("");
  const [password, setPassword] = useState("");
  const [role, setRole] = useState("Client");

  useEffect(() => {
    if (authState.isAuthenticated) {
      if (authState.role === "Manager") navigate("/managers-dashboard");
      else if (authState.role === "Staff") navigate("/staff-dashboard");
      else if (authState.role === "Client") navigate("/clients-dashboard");
    }
  }, [authState, navigate]);

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();

    if (!email || !password || !role) {
      alert("Please fill out all fields.");
      return;
    }

    // Simulate authentication — replace this with actual backend call
    const simulatedResponse = {
      success: true,
      user: { email },
      role,
      token: "mock-token",
    };

    if (simulatedResponse.success) {
      login({
        user: simulatedResponse.user,
        role: simulatedResponse.role,
        token: simulatedResponse.token,
      });
    }
  };

  return (
    <div className="login-container">
      {!authState.isAuthenticated ? (
        <>
          <h2>Login to Elegant Touch Nails</h2>
          <form onSubmit={handleSubmit} className="login-form">
            <label>
              Email:
              <input
                type="email"
                value={email}
                onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)}
                required
              />
            </label>

            <label>
              Password:
              <input
                type="password"
                value={password}
                onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
                required
              />
            </label>

            <label>
              Role:
              <select value={role} onChange={(e) => setRole(e.target.value)} required>
                <option value="Manager">Manager</option>
                <option value="Staff">Staff</option>
                <option value="Client">Client</option>
              </select>
            </label>

            <button type="submit">Login</button>
          </form>
        </>
      ) : (
        <p className="login-success">You are already logged in.</p>
      )}
    </div>
  );
};

export default LoginLandingPage;

ChatGPT said:

Great — you want to update your AuthContext to use real backend login with a POST /api/login call, and include the selected role, email, and password.

Here’s how to cleanly implement the real login function inside your existing AuthContext.js.

✅ Final AuthContext.js with async login(email, password, role)

js
// src/context/AuthContext.js
import React, { createContext, useState, useEffect } from "react";

export const AuthContext = createContext();

export const AuthProvider = ({ children }) => {
  const [authState, setAuthState] = useState({
    isAuthenticated: false,
    user: null,
    role: null,
  });

  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);

  useEffect(() => {
    const storedUser = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("user"));
    const storedRole = localStorage.getItem("role");

    if (storedUser && storedRole) {
      setAuthState({
        isAuthenticated: true,
        user: storedUser,
        role: storedRole,
      });
    }

    setLoading(false);
  }, []);

  // ✅ Real login using fetch to /api/login
  const login = async (email, password, role) => {
    try {
      const response = await fetch("/api/login", {
        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ email, password, role }),
      });

      const data = await response.json();

      if (response.ok) {
        const user = data.user;
        const userRole = user.Role || role; // Prefer backend-provided Role if available
        const token = data.token || ""; // Optional token

        // Persist to localStorage
        localStorage.setItem("user", JSON.stringify(user));
        localStorage.setItem("role", userRole);
        localStorage.setItem("token", token);

        // Set auth state
        setAuthState({
          isAuthenticated: true,
          user,
          role: userRole,
        });
      } else {
        console.error("Login failed:", data.message || "Invalid credentials");
        alert(data.message || "Login failed.");
      }
    } catch (err) {
      console.error("Error logging in:", err);
      alert("Server error during login.");
    }
  };

  const logout = () => {
    localStorage.clear();
    setAuthState({
      isAuthenticated: false,
      user: null,
      role: null,
    });
  };

  return (
    <AuthContext.Provider value={{ authState, login, logout, loading }}>
      {children}
    </AuthContext.Provider>
  );
};

✅ Backend /api/login Response Format (Required)

Make sure your backend returns this JSON format on successful login:

json
{
  "user": {
    "FullName": "John Doe",
    "Email": "john@example.com",
    "Role": "Manager"
  },
  "token": "abc123"
}

The frontend expects:

  • user → required

  • user.Role → preferred for setting role (fallback to selected role)

  • token → optional

✅ Frontend Usage

In your LoginLandingPage.js, pass the params correctly:

js
login(email, password, role); // Uses the async function from AuthContext

ChatGPT said:

Let’s debug this "Server error during login" step-by-step.

✅ Step 1: Confirm Your Frontend Request

Make sure the login function sends the correct JSON to your backend:

js
const response = await fetch("/api/login", {
  method: "POST",
  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
  body: JSON.stringify({ email, password, role }),
});

If the backend expects Email, Password, and Role (with capital letters), but you’re sending lowercase keys, it may fail.

🔍 Step 2: Check the Backend /api/login Route

Here’s what your Express route should look like (assuming MySQL and bcrypt):

js
// backend/routes/login.js
const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();
const bcrypt = require("bcrypt");
const db = require("../config/db");

router.post("/", async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password, role } = req.body;

  if (!email || !password || !role) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Missing credentials" });
  }

  try {
    let tableName = "";
    switch (role) {
      case "Manager":
        tableName = "Staff"; // assuming managers are staff with StaffID = 1
        break;
      case "Staff":
        tableName = "Staff";
        break;
      case "Client":
        tableName = "Clients";
        break;
      default:
        return res.status(400).json({ message: "Invalid role" });
    }

    const query = `SELECT * FROM ${tableName} WHERE Email = ?`;
    db.query(query, [email], async (err, results) => {
      if (err) return res.status(500).json({ message: "Database error" });
      if (results.length === 0) return res.status(401).json({ message: "User not found" });

      const user = results[0];

      const match = await bcrypt.compare(password, user.PasswordHash);
      if (!match) return res.status(401).json({ message: "Invalid password" });

      res.json({
        user: {
          FullName: user.FullName,
          Email: user.Email,
          Role: role,
        },
        token: "mock-jwt-token",
      });
    });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Login error:", err);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Server error" });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

Without this, req.body will be undefined and cause server errors.

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for the detailed code. You're currently mixing two separate login handlers:

  • One in controllers/loginController.js using exports.loginUser

  • Another directly in routes/login.js

They conflict.

🔴 Problem Summary

You have two login implementations:

  1. A controller-based login (loginUser), which:

    • Uses bcryptjs

    • Checks for a hardcoded manager

    • Uses user[0].Password

  2. A route-based login (router.post(...) in routes/login.js), which:

    • Uses bcrypt

    • Uses user.PasswordHash

    • Uses mock token

➡️ You only need ONE of these. Right now, your app is probably using the routes/login.js version, but your logic and hardcoded manager are in loginUser.

✅ Fix in 3 Steps

Step 1: Replace Route Logic with Your Controller Logic

Edit your routes/login.js file to look like this:

js
const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();
const { loginUser } = require("../controllers/loginController");

router.post("/", loginUser);

module.exports = router;

✅ This delegates the login POST request to the controller (loginUser), which includes your full logic.

Step 2: Fix Key Issue in Controller Code

In your controller, you're using this code for client/staff login:

js
const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, user[0].Password);

But for your hardcoded manager, you used this hash:

js
Password: "2b$10$..."

So make sure your database also stores passwords in the Password field, not PasswordHash.

If your Staff or Clients table uses PasswordHash, then modify this line:

js
const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, user[0].PasswordHash); // ← correct field name

✅ Optional: Clean Up Hardcoded User (Consistency)

Your hardcoded user has:

js
Role: "Salon Manager",
AccessLevel: "Manager",

But your frontend sends just:

js
role = "Manager"

So you're checking:

js
if (role === "Manager" && email === hardcodedUser.Email)

✅ That’s fine. Just ensure role consistency between frontend and backend.

✅ Step 3: Restart Server

After changes:

bash
npm run dev    # or however you run the server

Then try logging in again and check:

  • Terminal logs

  • Network → /api/login → Status 200 or 401?

  • Console → token and user object?

Final Notes

  • Remove the second login route that had mock logic and inline bcrypt

  • Rely solely on your loginUser controller for all roles

  • Use consistent password field names (Password or PasswordHash)

  • Only use one bcrypt library (prefer bcryptjs for cross-platform compatibility)

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing your full router and controller. You're close — the issue seems to lie in how you're destructuring the query result from MySQL. Let's fix it cleanly.

✅ Problem

In this line:

js
[user] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Clients WHERE Email = ?", [email]);

You're expecting user to be the actual rows, but mysql2 (or sometimes mysql) returns:

js
const [rows, fields] = await db.query(...);

So you're currently treating user as the row array, when it's actually the fields metadata.

✅ Fix

Change both queries from:

js
[user] = await db.query("...");

To:

js
const [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Clients WHERE Email = ?", [email]);

if (!rows || rows.length === 0) {
  return res.status(401).json({ message: "User not found" });
}

const dbUser = rows[0];

const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, dbUser.Password);
if (!isMatch) {
  return res.status(401).json({ message: "Invalid credentials" });
}

// ...continue with dbUser

Same fix for the Staff block.

✅ Full Fixed Controller Snippet

js
exports.loginUser = async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password, role } = req.body;

  if (!email || !password || !role) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Missing credentials" });
  }

  try {
    // ✅ Hardcoded manager check
    if (
      role === "Manager" &&
      email === hardcodedUser.Email &&
      (await bcrypt.compare(password, hardcodedUser.Password))
    ) {
      const tokenPayload = {
        id: hardcodedUser.StaffID,
        role: hardcodedUser.Role,
        accessLevel: hardcodedUser.AccessLevel,
      };

      const token = jwt.sign(tokenPayload, process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret", {
        expiresIn: "1h",
      });

      return res.status(200).json({
        token,
        role: hardcodedUser.Role,
        accessLevel: hardcodedUser.AccessLevel,
        user: hardcodedUser,
      });
    }

    // ✅ Database login
    let rows;
    if (role === "Client") {
      [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Clients WHERE Email = ?", [email]);
    } else {
      [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Staff WHERE Email = ?", [email]);
    }

    if (!rows || rows.length === 0) {
      return res.status(401).json({ message: "User not found" });
    }

    const dbUser = rows[0];

    const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, dbUser.Password);
    if (!isMatch) {
      return res.status(401).json({ message: "Invalid credentials" });
    }

    const accessLevel = role === "Client" ? "Client" : dbUser.AccessLevel;
    const tokenPayload = {
      id: role === "Client" ? dbUser.ClientID : dbUser.StaffID,
      role,
      accessLevel,
    };

    const token = jwt.sign(tokenPayload, process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret", {
      expiresIn: "1h",
    });

    return res.status(200).json({
      token,
      role,
      accessLevel,
      user: dbUser,
    });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Login Error:", err);
    return res.status(500).json({ message: "Internal Server Error" });
  }
};

IssueFix
MySQL returns [rows, fields]Destructure rows and access [0]
You were using user[0] before correctly setting userRename to dbUser from rows[0]
user.length === 0 throws on undefinedSafely check rows && rows.length === 0

  • Return additional user details (e.g. name, role) in the token

Here's your cleaned-up loginUser controller using only role (without accessLevel), and correcting the MySQL query destructuring:

✅ authController.js — Updated Code (No accessLevel)

js
const bcrypt = require("bcryptjs");
const jwt = require("jsonwebtoken");
const db = require("../config/db");

const hardcodedUser = {
  StaffID: 1,
  FullName: "John Downer",
  Email: "john2520@eleganttouch.com",
  Password: "2b$10$sNG7Kk71JJrYQrNxbGWfNOw0pH.zALEnz3yiy17PzWOYo5hzgbMO6", // hashed "FJHFFJY"
  Role: "Manager",
};

exports.loginUser = async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password, role } = req.body;

  if (!email || !password || !role) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Missing credentials" });
  }

  try {
    // ✅ Hardcoded Manager login
    if (
      role === "Manager" &&
      email === hardcodedUser.Email &&
      (await bcrypt.compare(password, hardcodedUser.Password))
    ) {
      const tokenPayload = {
        id: hardcodedUser.StaffID,
        role: hardcodedUser.Role,
      };

      const token = jwt.sign(tokenPayload, process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret", {
        expiresIn: "1h",
      });

      return res.status(200).json({
        token,
        role: hardcodedUser.Role,
        user: hardcodedUser,
      });
    }

    // ✅ Database login for Client or Staff
    let rows;
    if (role === "Client") {
      [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Clients WHERE Email = ?", [email]);
    } else {
      [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Staff WHERE Email = ?", [email]);
    }

    if (!rows || rows.length === 0) {
      return res.status(401).json({ message: "User not found" });
    }

    const dbUser = rows[0];

    const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, dbUser.Password);
    if (!isMatch) {
      return res.status(401).json({ message: "Invalid credentials" });
    }

    const tokenPayload = {
      id: role === "Client" ? dbUser.ClientID : dbUser.StaffID,
      role,
    };

    const token = jwt.sign(tokenPayload, process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret", {
      expiresIn: "1h",
    });

    return res.status(200).json({
      token,
      role,
      user: dbUser,
    });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Login Error:", err);
    return res.status(500).json({ message: "Internal Server Error" });
  }
};

✅ Summary of Changes

  • Removed all references to accessLevel.

  • Used correct destructuring from MySQL query: [rows] = await db.query(...).

  • Renamed query result to dbUser for clarity.

  • Token now includes only id and role.

✅ ENHANCED LOGIN CONTROLLER WITH BETTER DEBUGGING

js
const bcrypt = require("bcryptjs");
const jwt = require("jsonwebtoken");
const db = require("../config/db");

const hardcodedUser = {
  StaffID: 1,
  FullName: "John Downer",
  Email: "john2520@eleganttouch.com",
  Password: "2b$10$sNG7Kk71JJrYQrNxbGWfNOw0pH.zALEnz3yiy17PzWOYo5hzgbMO6", // hashed "FJHFFJY"
  Role: "Manager",
};

exports.loginUser = async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password, role } = req.body;
  console.log("Login Request Body:", { email, password, role });

  if (!email || !password || !role) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Missing credentials" });
  }

  try {
    // ✅ Hardcoded Manager Login
    if (
      role === "Manager" &&
      email === hardcodedUser.Email &&
      (await bcrypt.compare(password, hardcodedUser.Password))
    ) {
      const token = jwt.sign(
        { id: hardcodedUser.StaffID, role: hardcodedUser.Role },
        process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret",
        { expiresIn: "1h" }
      );

      return res.status(200).json({
        token,
        role: hardcodedUser.Role,
        user: hardcodedUser,
      });
    }

    // ✅ Dynamic Client or Staff Lookup
    let rows;
    if (role === "Client") {
      [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Clients WHERE Email = ?", [email]);
    } else {
      [rows] = await db.query("SELECT * FROM Staff WHERE Email = ?", [email]);
    }

    if (!rows || rows.length === 0) {
      return res.status(401).json({ message: "User not found" });
    }

    const user = rows[0];
    const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, user.Password);
    if (!isMatch) {
      return res.status(401).json({ message: "Invalid credentials" });
    }

    const token = jwt.sign(
      {
        id: role === "Client" ? user.ClientID : user.StaffID,
        role,
      },
      process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret",
      { expiresIn: "1h" }
    );

    return res.status(200).json({
      token,
      role,
      user,
    });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ Server Login Error:", err.message, err.stack);
    return res.status(500).json({ message: "Internal Server Error" });
  }
};

Thanks — this error:

perl
{
  "error": "Duplicate entry 'john2520@eleganttouch.com' for key 'staff.Email'"
}

means that your Staff table has a UNIQUE constraint on the Email column, and you're trying to insert another row with the same email (john2520@eleganttouch.com) that already exists.

✅ What This Tells Us

You're trying to insert or register a new staff member using an email that already exists in the Staff table, even though the hardcoded manager is meant to be "virtual" (not in the DB).

That means some part of your app (possibly the frontend) is trying to insert this hardcoded manager into the database — which is not needed and causing the conflict.

✅ Solution

🔒 Option 1: Remove Hardcoded Manager From DB

Since you already have a hardcoded manager (john2520@eleganttouch.com) handled in code:

  1. Manually delete the conflicting record from your Staff table:

    sql
    DELETE FROM Staff WHERE Email = 'john2520@eleganttouch.com';

  2. This will prevent the "duplicate entry" when any part of your code references that user.

✅ OR Option 2: Change Hardcoded Manager Email

If for some reason you need that email in the DB for other logic:

  • Update your hardcodedUser.Email to something else, e.g., manager@eleganttouch.com.

Then, only that login path will accept it, and the DB won’t conflict.

🧼 Bonus: Defensive Check

If you accidentally have a signup or registration function that’s trying to insert this hardcoded user into the DB, add a condition to skip it.

Example:

js
if (email === "john2520@eleganttouch.com") {
  return res.status(400).json({ message: "This email is reserved for the hardcoded manager." });
}

Thanks! The error you're seeing:

pgsql
SyntaxError: JSON.parse: unexpected character at line 1 column 1 of the JSON data

means that your frontend is trying to parse something as JSON, but the backend is returning a non-JSON error response (like plain HTML or a server error page).

🔍 Root Cause

The backend is likely returning an HTML error page (e.g., from an unhandled error, 500, or CORS issue), but the frontend is trying to run:

js
const data = await response.json();

Which throws this JSON.parse error when the response is not JSON.

✅ How to Debug It

  1. Use DevTools > Network tab:

    • Go to the browser > F12 > Network > submit the login form again.

    • Click on the login request.

    • Check:

      • Status code (likely 500 or 404?)

      • Response body (will probably be HTML or error string)

      • Request payload (email, password, role) — make sure it’s correct.

  2. Log the raw response in frontend before parsing:

In your AuthContext.js, find where you call fetch("/api/login"), and modify like this:

js
const response = await fetch("/api/login", {
  method: "POST",
  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
  body: JSON.stringify({ email, password, role }),
});

const text = await response.text(); // 🟡 Use .text() instead of .json()
console.log("Raw login response:", text);

try {
  const data = JSON.parse(text);
  // Continue processing
} catch (err) {
  console.error("Failed to parse login response as JSON:", err);
}

Thanks for sharing your LoginLandingPage.js. You've got a critical bug here:

❌ Problem

You're not actually using the real backend login() function from AuthContext.

In handleSubmit(), you're doing this:

js
const simulatedResponse = {
  success: true,
  user: { email },
  role,
  token: "mock-token",
};

if (simulatedResponse.success) {
  login({
    user: simulatedResponse.user,
    role: simulatedResponse.role,
    token: simulatedResponse.token,
  });
}

⚠️ This bypasses the backend call completely, and it's sending the wrong structure to login(), which expects:

js
login(email, password, role);

✅ Fix

✅ Replace your handleSubmit() function with this:

js
const handleSubmit = (e) => {
  e.preventDefault();

  if (!email || !password || !role) {
    alert("Please fill out all fields.");
    return;
  }

  login(email, password, role); // ← this is the correct call
};

This will now send the actual credentials to the backend POST /api/auth/login endpoint.

✅ Bonus Debug Logging (Optional but Recommended)

Inside AuthContext.js, in your login() function, add:

js

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing all the relevant code. Let's resolve the three main issues you’re facing:

✅ ISSUE 1: Manager login returns "User not found"

Your loginUser function has this condition:

js
if (
  role === "Manager" &&
  email === hardcodedUser.Email &&
  (await bcrypt.compare(password, hardcodedUser.Password))
)
console.log("🟢 Matched hardcoded Manager login");
{
   // issue: this block runs **unconditionally**

❌ Problem:

This block:

js
if (...) console.log(...);
{
  const token = jwt.sign(...);
  return res.status(200).json(...);
}

means the token code always runs, not only when if is true — because of misplaced braces. So when the password is wrong or doesn't match the hardcoded email, it still goes through and logs in with the hardcoded user.

✅ Fix:

Wrap the block inside the if properly:

js
if (
  role === "Manager" &&
  email === hardcodedUser.Email &&
  (await bcrypt.compare(password, hardcodedUser.Password))
) {
  console.log("🟢 Matched hardcoded Manager login");

  const token = jwt.sign(
    { id: hardcodedUser.StaffID, role: hardcodedUser.Role },
    process.env.JWT_SECRET || "secret",
    { expiresIn: "1h" }
  );

  return res.status(200).json({
    token,
    role: hardcodedUser.Role,
    user: hardcodedUser,
  });
}

✅ ISSUE 2: Logging in as Staff shows "You are already logged in" but no navigation links

🧠 Likely Causes:

  • The login did succeed (based on message), but:

    • authState.role is either missing, empty, or misspelled.

    • Navigation is only rendered when role is valid (see navItems[role]).

✅ Debug Plan:

  1. Log authState in the Navigation.js component:

js
console.log("AuthState in Navigation:", authState);

  1. Check that authState.role is exactly "Staff" — case-sensitive!

  2. Check AuthContext.js → make sure the role is stored in authState properly.

✅ Expected structure:

js
authState = {
  isAuthenticated: true,
  token: "jwt_token",
  user: { ... },
  role: "Staff"
}

✅ If role is not stored:

Go to the login logic in AuthContext.js and confirm:

js
setAuthState({
  isAuthenticated: true,
  token: data.token,
  user: data.user,
  role: data.role, // 👈 ensure this line exists
});

✅ ISSUE 3: AppBar is rendered, but no links for Manager or Staff

This is likely tied to Issue 2.

Your code does:

js
{!isMobile && role &&
  navItems[role]?.map((item) => (
    <Link ...>{item.label}</Link>
  ))
}

So if role is undefined, misspelled (e.g., "staff" instead of "Staff"), or not included in navItems, it silently renders nothing.

✅ Summary of Fixes:

  1. Fix misplaced block in loginUser for Manager:

    js
    if (...) {
  // not after console.log
}

  2. Verify authState.role is correctly set in AuthContext.

  3. Add a console.log in Navigation.js to inspect authState.

  4. Double-check your navItems uses exact roles: "Manager", "Staff", "Client"

✅ Bonus: Add Fallback in Navigation.js

To help debug issues in future, add:

js
{!navItems[role] && (
  <span style={{ color: "yellow", marginLeft: "1rem" }}>
    Unknown Role: {role}
  </span>
)}

This will visibly warn you if the role doesn’t match anything expected.

ChatGPT said:

Your Navigation component is already well-structured and functional. However, here are recommended improvements and refinements to optimize user experience, styling consistency, and code maintainability:

✅ Recommended Code Improvements

1. Highlight Active Link

Add visual feedback for the currently active route using useLocation().

js
import { useLocation } from "react-router-dom";

Then inside the component:

js
const location = useLocation();

Update desktop and mobile rendering:

jsx
<Link
  to={item.to}
  key={item.to}
  style={{
    ...linkStyle,
    borderBottom: location.pathname === item.to ? "2px solid #fff" : "none",
  }}
>

And for mobile:

jsx
<ListItem
  button
  key={item.to}
  component={Link}
  to={item.to}
  selected={location.pathname === item.to}
>

2. Remove Unused Menu Items

The profile menu currently shows “Profile” and “My Account” which are not functional. Either wire them up or remove:

jsx
<MenuItem onClick={handleLogout}>Logout</MenuItem>

Only keep this if you're not yet implementing profile/account pages.

3. Collapse Drawer on Navigation

Make drawer close after navigation by adding a onClick inside each <ListItem>:

jsx
<ListItem
  button
  key={item.to}
  component={Link}
  to={item.to}
  onClick={toggleDrawer}
>

4. Improve Mobile Drawer Styling

Add padding or a custom background if needed:

jsx
<Box
  sx={{
    width: 250,
    backgroundColor: "#fafafa",
    height: "100%",
  }}
  role="presentation"
  onClick={toggleDrawer}
>

5. Graceful Handling When role is Undefined

To avoid crashes on refresh or logout edge cases, add fallback:

js
const itemsToRender = navItems[role] || [];

Then in render:

js
itemsToRender.map(...)

6. Add Tooltip on Desktop Icons (Optional UX Enhancement)

js
import Tooltip from "@mui/material/Tooltip";

Then wrap desktop links:

jsx
<Tooltip title={item.label} arrow>
  <Link to={item.to} key={item.to} style={linkStyle}>
    {item.icon}
    <span style={{ marginLeft: 6 }}>{item.label}</span>
  </Link>
</Tooltip>

🎨 linkStyle Enhancements

Update linkStyle to include hover effect for better UX:

js
const linkStyle = {
  color: "white",
  textDecoration: "none",
  marginRight: "20px",
  display: "flex",
  alignItems: "center",
  fontWeight: "bold",
  fontSize: "1rem",
  padding: "6px 10px",
  transition: "0.3s",
};

const activeLinkStyle = {
  borderBottom: "2px solid white",
};

Optionally, wrap with a custom NavLink component to encapsulate active detection and styling.

✅ Summary of Changes

AreaAction
Active StylingHighlight active route in nav and drawer using useLocation()
Menu ItemsRemove or implement non-functional "Profile" and "My Account"
Drawer UXCollapse drawer after navigation
Responsive UIImprove drawer styling and consistency
Role SafetyPrevent nav crash if role is undefined
Visual FeedbackAdd hover effects, border underline, or tooltip on nav links

open={Boolean(anchorEl)}

anchorOrigin={{ vertical: "top", horizontal: "right" }}

transformOrigin={{ vertical: "top", horizontal: "right" }}

>

<MenuItem onClick={handleClose}>Profile</MenuItem>

<MenuItem onClick={handleClose}>My Account</MenuItem>

<MenuItem onClick={handleLogout}>Logout</MenuItem>

</Menu>

</>

) : (

<MenuItem

onClick={() => navigate("/login")}

sx={{ color: "white", cursor: "pointer", marginLeft: 2 }}

>

Login

</MenuItem>

)}

</Toolbar>

</AppBar>

</Box >

);

}
